info.title: SPARQL router API
info.description:
SPARQL router serves SPARQL query results for developers and data fanatics who don't know the SPARQL language.


See more on the [README](https://github.com/ColinMaudry/sparql-router).


[YAML](swagger.yaml) and [JSON](swagger.json) sources for this API spec, written with [Swagger Editor](http://editor.swagger.io/).

basicAuth.description: HTTP Basic Authentication. Works over `HTTP` and `HTTPS`

get.summary: Query that returns the results of a SPARQL query. The extension determines the requested format.
get.description:
The queries in `/tables` return tabular data, that is data in columns, with column headers. These results are typically returned as JSON, CSV or XML.


The queries in `/graphs` return graph data, or [RDF triples](https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf11-primer/#section-data-model), in the form of `subject predicate object` statements. These results are typically returned as [Turtle](https://www.w3.org/TeamSubmission/turtle/#sec-examples),  [JSON-LD](http://json-ld.org/) or [RDF/XML](https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-syntax-grammar/#section-Syntax).


**The returned format depends on the chosen extension**. See valid extensions [here](https://github.com/ColinMaudry/sparql-router/blob/master/config/default.json).


Examples:


- [/tables/test.csv](/tables/test.csv)
- [/graphs/test.ttl](/tables/test.csv)

parameters.name: queryType
parameters.description: Either `tables` or `graphs` depending on the type of query.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the query to trigger.

parameters.name: extension
parameters.description: A valid extension to determine the format of the results. See [the supported extensions](https://github.com/ColinMaudry/sparql-router/blob/master/config/default.json).

200.description: The result of the SPARQL query.

get.summary: Query that returns the results of a SPARQL query. The Accept header determines the requested format.
get.description:
The queries in `/tables` return tabular data, that is data in columns, with column headers. These results are typically returned as JSON, CSV or XML.


The queries in `/graphs` return graph data, or [RDF triples](https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf11-primer/#section-data-model), in the form of `subject predicate object` statements. These results are typically returned as [Turtle](https://www.w3.org/TeamSubmission/turtle/#sec-examples),  [JSON-LD](http://json-ld.org/) or [RDF/XML](https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-syntax-grammar/#section-Syntax).
**The returned format depends on the chosen content-type**. See possible content-types [here](https://github.com/ColinMaudry/sparql-router/blob/master/config/default.json).

parameters.name: queryType
parameters.description: Either `tables` or `graphs` depending on the type of query.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the query to trigger.

parameters.name: Accept
parameters.description: One of the [supported content-types](https://github.com/ColinMaudry/sparql-router/blob/master/config/default.json). If `null` it will be the default content-type of the endpoint.

200.description: The results of the SPARQL query (schema only applies to `application/sparql-results+json`).

406.description: The provided content-type is not valid for this type of query.

post.summary: Creates a new query or updates an existing one.
post.description:
The new query must be passed in the body of the request.


If you `POST` to `/tables`, the query must be a [SELECT](https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/#select) query and consequently return tabular data.


If you `POST` to `/graphs`, the query must be a [CONSTRUCT](https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/#construct) or [DESCRIBE](https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/#describe) query and return a graph.

parameters.name: queryType
parameters.description: Either `tables`, `graphs` or `update` depending on the type of query.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the query to create or update.

400.description: The `POST` request body is empty or the syntax of the submitted query is invalid.

401.description: The provided credientials are not valid.

413.description: The query provided is bigger than the allowed size.

500.description: Something went wrong during the creation of the query.

parameters.name: queryType
parameters.description: Either `tables`, `graphs` or `update` depending on the type of query.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the query to delete.

500.description: There was an error deleting the query.

get.summary: Query that executes a SPARQL Update query.
get.description:
The queries in `/update` execute a SPARQL Update query on the configured SPARQL endpoint. A SPARQL Update query does not return data.
The HTTP status code of the response determines whether the update was successful or not.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the query to trigger.

200.description: The update was successfully performed. The code can vary as it depends on the SPARQL endpoint configuration.

400.description: There was an error with the executed SPARQL Update query.

get.summary: Sends a query directly to the configured endpoint, without using a canned query.
get.description: Example: [/sparql?query=select%20*%20where%20%7B%3Fs%20%3Fp%20%3Fo%7D%20limit%201](/sparql?query=select%20*%20where%20%7B%3Fs%20%3Fp%20%3Fo%7D%20limit%201), which is the URL encoded version of `select * where {?s ?p ?o} limit 1`.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description: The text of the query, URL encoded. SPARQL Update queries may not work depending on endpoint configuration.

parameters.name: Accept
parameters.description: The content-type you want for the returned results. If `null` it will be the default content-type of the endpoint.

200.description: The results of the SPARQL query.

400.description: Something is wrong with the query.
